Award.AwardTitle: Development of computational methods with applications to studying equilibrium properties of clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Vladimir Mandelshtam of the University of California Irvine is supported by the Theoretical and Computational Chemistry program for research to apply the variational Gaussian wavepacket (VGW) method to Lennard-Jones clusters, water clusters and fullerenes in order to assess the importance of quantum effects in clusters. Equilibrium data such as the equilibrium structures and thermodynamic properties will be calculated for the clusters. The research includes a second component in which Mandelstam will collaborate with an experimentalist to develop and extend his Filter Diagonalization Method (FDM) for 3-, 4- and 5-D NMR experiments.

Mandelshtam's filter diagonalization approach has great utility in multi-dimensional NMR signal processing, and the spectral analysis code resulting from this project will be distributed free to NMR researchers worldwide. It is expected to reduce NMR experimental times and possibly make certain multidimensional NMR experiments newly feasible. Software previously supplied by the PI is used by thousands of researchers. The extension of this technique should have a large impact on the accurate rapid processing and filtering of any multidimensional spectroscopic signals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this research was both on the development of new theoretical/computational methods for simulating quantum many-body systems and the applications of these methods to study the properties of clusters (e.g., rare gas clusters) and quantum  liquids (e.g., liquid para-hydrogen).  It turns out that a number of real atomic or molecular systems are well  represented by a universal model in which the interaction between the particles are given in terms of the Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential, while the quantum effects are characterized by a single parameter, the de-Boer quantum delocalization length, Λ, varying from Λ=0.01 (corresponding to nearly classical xenon) to Λ=0.44 (corresponding to strongly quantum helium).  This circumstance justifies studies of quantum LJ systems not only as a function of conventional thermodynamic variables, such as temperature, T, or size, N, but also as a  function of Λ. Consequently, studies of LJ clusters as a function of N, T and Λ were carried out resulting in phase diagrams that revealed some interesting either generic or system-dependent properties. Most interestingly, it was demonstrated that the quantum fluctuations are akin to thermal fluctuations in the role they play in structural transitions, e.g.  order-disorder transitions. Other outcomes of this research include development of numerical tools, such as the Filter Diagonalization Method (FDM), for efficient spectral analysis of time-domain data, e.g., that measured in the Nucler Magnetic Resonance experiments.

The eventual impact of this research on large scale quantum simulations may be profound.  In addition, FDM as a general algorithm for spectral analysis of one- or multi-dimensional data is being used by many research groups with the freely available FDM codes written either by the PI's group or by others.
The project contributed to training of two postdoctoral fellows, at least four graduate students, and one undergraduate student.
